div.p: Long Beach was the fastest growing city from 1902-1910 (Bluff Heights Neighborhood Association, 2016). As the city grew, so did the infrastructure that connected this sprawling suburb to other larger urban metropolis like Los Angeles. Most importantly was the transformation of this suburb from a small beach-town to a “port-town”, global center of trade and commerce. (Port of Long Beach, 2016). The Port of Long Beach was established in 1911 and it quickly expanded by creating transportation infrastructures like railways and roadways that would connect the inner lands of the Los Angeles region to the sea. Along with the discovery aof oil in the 1920s and the shipyards built in the 1930s, Long Beach became an industrial suburb that attracted white-working class families (Long Beach Are Convention and Visitors Bureau, 2016). Similar to the industrial suburbs built in Homestead, Pennsylvania, the booming industries of manufacturing and goods movement provided the means necessary to live in comfort and aspire to own property (Nicolaides, 199).

note.placeName: From Beach Livin' to industrial suburb. (Long Beach Waterfront)
note.p: From beach livin' to industrial suburb; small town to port town. Long Beach witnessed extraordinary growth and industrial transformation in the early 20th Century.
